I agree with Alex and Andrei and, while I do feel we need to do a better job at treating mental illness in this country, we have to be careful not to provide another "out" for the gun advocates. We don't yet know what, if any, help Adam Lanza was getting. We do know that his mother was a gun enthusiast, took him shooting at a shooting range, and surrounded him with weapons and ammunition that he ultimately used to murder her and 26 other innocent people. So when we discuss the lack of gun control and oversight in this country, we should be using this very household as an example of "freedom" run amok. It has to be said: It is unlikely this would have happened if Adam Lanza hadn't had such easy access to his mother's WMDs. More here: http://omyc.wordpress.com/2012/12/16/what_do_we_do/

In all the coverage of this story, I've not seen one reputable source saying that the killer had a mental illness. His classmates said he had a developmental disorder; I don't think his classmates are psychologists or psychiatrists able to make that diagnosis. Neighbors said he didn't make eye contact; there are an awful lot of shy people in the world who never in a million years would dream of shooting anyone, much less a bunch of elementary school students & their teachers & staff. The killer's dad isn't talking at all, & the older brother doesn't seem to have been much  involved in his mother's household, & again is not a mental health professional. It seems to me to be more prudent to wait to see if there's any sort of professional recognized diagnosis of the killer's mental health or personality issues before making the story be about the admittedly shameful state of mental health care in the U.S. today. And regardless of whether the killer had mental health or personality issues, w/o easy access to guns whose purpose is solely to kill humans, the killer would not have been able to murder all those children & teachers. The real issue here isn't mental health, it's America's obsession w/ & easy access to guns.
People with guns kill alot of other people, yes guns kill people and high power weapons kill even more people.

The real issue is what to our children about the Sandy Hook nutcase. This was a young man who should have been receiving the kind of psychiatric help he needed, and if the issue of violence came up he should have been evaluated for hospitalization.

Unfortunately, hospitalization would have been difficult except in the most extreme cases. In the 1960s the American Civil Liberties Union brought a number of cases opposing the practice of involuntary hospitalization.

A few high-profile cases had shown where the practice had been abused so they pushed to make it extremely difficult to force anyone into a mental institution. It was a time of acute sensitivity to civil liberties and the drug revolution had made it much easier to treat patients on an outpatient basis. States were looking at costs and lawyers were giving hospitals fits.

By focusing on guns the issue of caring for the mentally ill is getting sidelined. Moreover, the way the media has sensationalized this case, and every case before it, the wrong kind of person is getting a good idea of how to go out in a blaze of notoriety. A psychotic individual is getting schooled in exactly what it takes to finally "matter." This is not what they need to be hearing. Copycat killings are already happening and will as long as the networks and cable keep obsessing about it, politicians use it to work an agenda and causes and crusades are using it to organize around.

Time to deal with the real issue and its not guns.

Any reasoning person should understand  that the increase in the deficit is mainly due to lack of revenues from the still badly depressed economy, and not due to any real increase in entitlement programs.  As Professor Krugman explained at least a year ago, spending on unemployment benefits or social programs is nothing new, it's something every civilized and advanced economy has always done, and it's the very sensible use of a safety net that we've had for years.  It's really hard to understand how so many people fail to grasp what Keynes taught us, and Paul Krugman has reminded us of many times since - that severe slumps are not the time to cut back on government spending, but precisely the time to ramp it up.  I just keep thinking of a group of guys from Texas who built a large convenience store that languished in very weak sales for several years until the state finally built a service road that began funneling hundreds of cars off of I-35 into their parking lot.  If a simple service road could have such an effect on their business, why can't they see how other government spending on new technologies, infrastructure and education could have even more benefits for everyone else?

In her book "Nimisha's Ship", science fiction author Anne McCaffrey describes a matriarchal society in which a young woman - 18 or so - has a child early, with the assistance of a partner who is contracted for a limited duration (namely, until a live birth). Then, the biological mother goes off to continue her education or work while her own mother (by this point presumably in her late thirties or early forties) takes care of the child - and so on through the next generations.

I've often wondered what the pros and cons of such a system would be if it were really put into practice. I can see obvious drawbacks, e.g. the marginal role of the father, but certainly among its pros would be the combination of the physical youth of the biological parent with the emotional/financial/etc. maturity of the caretaking parent.

And let's all remember the multiplier effect, where government spending of one trillion ultimately creates five trillion in national income. Of course the process takes time, and the exact number depends on the propensities to save and to consume, so let's work with five trillion for a minute. What is the percentage of taxation required to collect the one trillion that the government spent? The answer is 20% if the multiplier is 5.

I will bet you 5 dollars that the Republicians have not taken into account the multiplier effect when they say that government spending is bad. In fact government spending ultimately pays for itself, if the economy is allowed to grow.

Right now we have a growth problem, not a debt problem. The Fed is the only government institution trying to make the economy grow. The Fed has powerful weapons to make the economy grow, including interest rates and purchasing government bonds. The other branches of the government, including Congress, should recognize economic growth as a goal and adopt policies and budgets that foster economic growth.

Spending money on education, health care, law enforcement, infrastructure, fire fighting, and other worthy causes, helps the economy grow. And ultimately the government gets the money back in increased tax revenue.

That's the multiplier effect. It's how we end depressions and get the country moving again.

Thanks to Dr. Krugman for this analysis of what is driving the deficit and what can most readily reduce it. To restate Dr. Krugman's points even more simply:

1. The U.S. has a fiscal 2012 budget deficit of roughly $1 trillion.
2. Restoring economic growth would cut the U.S. deficit by $600 billion ($450 billion in new revenues plus $150 billion in reduced federal spending on unemployment insurance, food stamps and similar safety net expenditures.)
3. The remaining deficit of $400 billion is sustainable, especially at the higher levels of GNP that a recovery will bring.
4. Job 1 is therefore creating and sustaining economic growth.

--ANetliner
